Rai's H7437101 Nissan Skyline 2000GT-R (KPGC10) 1971 Fuji Masters 250km 2nd Place K. Takahashi

Purchased: 2015
Manufacturer page: http://www.hiko7plus.co.jp/item/H7437101/

Nissan's dominance in Japanese touring car racing began May 3rd, 1969 with the Skyline's first win in the 1969 JAF Grand Prix race. Nissan went on to rack up 11 consecutive outright or class victories in 1969 and and an amazing 24 consecutive outright or class victories in 1970 with the PGC10 (sedan) model. The KPGC10 (coupe) model made it's debut on March 7th, 1971 but the first win didn't come until the next race (don't worry, PGC10s still were victorious).

By October 1971, Nissan had racked up 14 more consecutive outright or class victories for a total of 49. The 49th being the 1971 Fuji Masters 250km race. Kunimitsu Takahashi, in the red #1 KPGC10, qualified in first place followed by fellow factory drivers Motoharu Kurosawa in 2nd and M. Kitano in 3rd. Takahashi would finish in 2nd place behind Kurosawa. For some vintage footage of the race see the following:
Part 1: Best Motoring Racing History 4, Part 1
Part 2: Best Motoring Racing History 4, Part 2

Considering they had already secured 49 consecutive victories, Nissan was confident they would claim their 50th victory in December. In fact, they were so confident that they preemptively took out ads in Japan’s major newspapers telling race fans to watch them clinch the deal at the upcoming Fuji Tourist Trophy. Mazda had other plans and Nissan’s 50th win was delayed until March 1972.

Takahashi went on to launch Team Kunimitsu in 1992. He continued racing for this team in the JGTC series and retired from racing in 1999.

As for the model, Rai's used a Kyohso KPGC10 as the base. As such, it's not quite as nice as the newer Ebbro KPGC10s. Until recently, Rai's was the only manufacturer to release this model. Ignition Models released their version late last year. Also, this particular model has been autographed by Takahashi.
